abstracts.cdata!:
While the outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability is unlikely, and institutional
            development impacts are modest. Four major lessons are drawn
            from the experience of the project: a) project management,
            as an intrinsic element of success, requires human
            resources, and management procedures, adapted to an
            administration which, de facto, is then, not yet in place.
            These difficulties could be overcome through the early
            provision of training for managers, and, adequate tools on
            performance indicators and monitoring criteria for project
            implementation; b) effectiveness of institutional support
            was, and remains a valid objective of the project; yet, and
            although the project did succeed in creating structures to
            reach external support, it often omitted the improvement of
            basic training of agents working within these structures.
            Such training would translate institutional support into a
            better application of the forestry law, which is the
            ultimate aim of institutional support; c) given that the
            project's activities did not include administrative
            interventions onto the natural resources, the assessment
            report concluded an economic analysis of the project was
            impossible; however, the same assessment suggested tax
            revenue increases, which consisted on reforming forest
            taxation. Although the law has not yet materialized, the new
            investment operation should be subjected to an economic
            analysis, and fiscal impact study that quantifies the
            expected economic, and tax benefits; and, d) turning a
            problem project into a successful project required
            instilling a sense of urgency to motivate, and accomplish
            the vision of economic, ecological, and social significance,
            that materialized in the policy framework that guided
            forestry planning, and monitoring.

5077591.majtheme: Public sector governance,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will: (a) contribute to a
            better use of forestry resources by implementing, on a pilot
            basis, a management plan in the depleted coastal zone; (b)
            reinforce the strategic planning and operational capacity of
            government institutions in the forestry sector; (c) resume
            forestry and environmental research activities; (d) make
            forestry and environment training more practical and
            tailored to the needs of the private sector and to
            conservation needs; (e) help prevent environmental
            degradation through the implementation of recommendations
            from key environmental studies; and (f) support the
            Government in the creation and maintenance of wildlife
            reserves. The project will include the following components
            in order to meet the above objectives: institutional
            strengthening, forestry and environment training, forestry
            and environment research, forest inventory and
            rehabilitation, and creation and maintenance of reserves.
